trial_identification.studytitle: Mobility in older adults receiving hospital based rehabilitation: A pilot study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Reducing length of stay and improving mobility by increasing physical activity in older adults receiving hospital based rehabilitation: A pilot study.

interventions.interventions: Subjects in the intervention group will receive 'enhanced physical activity'. This will involve daily individual sessions provided by a physiotherapist or physiotherapy assistant. Subjects will perform exercises that are appropriate to their functional level, with an emphasis on mobility tasks. The duration of the session will vary, depending on the patient's tolerance, but will range from 5 to 60 minutes. These sessions will be in addition to any other therapy subjects are already receiving, and will be provided from enrolment until discharge from sub-acute care.
interventions.comparator: usual care, which may include physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech pathology, nursing, medical care and other allied health services as required.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: admission and discharge from sub acute care

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: admission and discharge from sub acute care

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Barthel index, which is a global measure of functional independence
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: admission and discharge from sub acute care, 3 months post discharge

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Australian Quality of Life (AQol), which measures quality of life
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Admission, Discharge and 3 months post discharge

secondaryOutcome.outcome: de Morton Mobility Index (DEMMI), which measures mobility.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: older adults admitted to a specialist aged care facility, with 'improve gait/ or mobility' as a goal of admission
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: enrolled in other intervention trials. Primary reason for admission is to await residential care Identified on admission as not requiring physiotherapy. There are medical restrictions preventing mobilisation.

trial_design.concealment: computer generated allocation schedule held by a third party.
trial_design.sequence: Blocked, stratified randomisation. Participants will be stratified based on functional level into one of two groups; either 'nonambulant' (unable to walk, or requires assistance of 2 people) or 'ambulant' (requires assistance of one person or independent with walking). Computer generated allocation will be used to randomly assign participants.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of this project is to examine whether a particular level of physical activity while in hospital leads patients to have faster or better recovery of walking when they leave hospital. This is important, as many older people admitted to hospital may have problems with their walking. The results of this research may help us develop treatments to help older people recover faster and more completely.
